question: According to IFRS standards, what is a key difference in energy management reporting requirements between the Building Products & Furnishings industry and the Real Estate industry?
optionA: Only the Real Estate industry must report on renewable energy percentage
optionB: Only the Building Products & Furnishings industry must report on grid electricity percentage
optionC: The Real Estate industry must report energy consumption by property subsector, while Building Products & Furnishings reports it as a whole
optionD: The Building Products & Furnishings industry must report energy ratings, while Real Estate does not
optionE: There are no significant differences in energy management reporting requirements
answer: C: The Real Estate industry must report energy consumption by property subsector, while Building Products & Furnishings reports it as a whole
explanation: The Real Estate industry is required to disclose energy consumption data separately for each property subsector, as specified in IF-RE-130a.2. In contrast, the Building Products & Furnishings industry reports energy consumption as a whole for the company, without breaking it down by property type or subsector.
references: IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Building Products & Furnishings
IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Real Estate
pairing_explanation: Both industries deal with materials for buildings, offering a perspective on sustainability in product lifecycle and land use.

question: When reporting on water management, what is a key difference between the Building Products & Furnishings industry and the Real Estate industry according to IFRS standards?
optionA: Only the Real Estate industry must report on water stress
optionB: The Building Products & Furnishings industry reports on water quality, while Real Estate does not
optionC: Real Estate must report water withdrawal by property subsector, while Building Products & Furnishings does not have this requirement
optionD: Building Products & Furnishings must report on wastewater treatment, while Real Estate does not
optionE: There are no significant differences in water management reporting requirements
answer: C: Real Estate must report water withdrawal by property subsector, while Building Products & Furnishings does not have this requirement
explanation: The Real Estate industry is required to disclose water withdrawal data separately for each property subsector, as specified in IF-RE-140a.2. The Building Products & Furnishings industry does not have a similar requirement to break down water usage by property type or subsector.
references: IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Building Products & Furnishings
IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Real Estate

question: How does the calculation of energy consumption differ between the Building Products & Furnishings industry and the Real Estate industry in IFRS sustainability reporting?
optionA: Building Products & Furnishings uses kWh, while Real Estate uses GJ
optionB: Real Estate calculates by property subsector, while Building Products & Furnishings calculates as a whole
optionC: Building Products & Furnishings includes transportation energy, while Real Estate does not
optionD: Real Estate uses a rolling average, while Building Products & Furnishings uses annual totals
optionE: There is no significant difference in energy consumption calculation methods
answer: B: Real Estate calculates by property subsector, while Building Products & Furnishings calculates as a whole
explanation: The Real Estate industry is required to calculate and disclose energy consumption data separately for each property subsector (IF-RE-130a.2), while the Building Products & Furnishings industry calculates and reports energy consumption as a whole for the company, without breaking it down by property type or subsector.
references: IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Building Products & Furnishings
IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Real Estate

optionC: Building Products & Furnishings includes water quality metrics, while Real Estate does not
optionD: Real Estate calculates water withdrawal by property subsector, while Building Products & Furnishings does not have this requirement
optionE: There is no significant difference in water-related metric calculations
answer: D: Real Estate calculates water withdrawal by property subsector, while Building Products & Furnishings does not have this requirement
explanation: The Real Estate industry is required to calculate and disclose water withdrawal data separately for each property subsector (IF-RE-140a.2), while the Building Products & Furnishings industry does not have a similar requirement to break down water usage calculations by property type or subsector.

question: How do the Building Products & Furnishings and Real Estate industries differ in their approach to reporting on climate change adaptation in IFRS sustainability disclosures?
optionA: Only Real Estate reports on properties in flood zones
optionB: Building Products & Furnishings focuses on product resilience, while Real Estate focuses on property resilience
optionC: Real Estate must report on climate scenarios, while Building Products & Furnishings does not
optionD: Building Products & Furnishings reports on supply chain climate risks, while Real Estate does not
optionE: There is no significant difference in climate change adaptation reporting
answer: A: Only Real Estate reports on properties in flood zones
explanation: The Real Estate industry has a specific requirement (IF-RE-450a.1) to disclose the area of properties located in 100-year flood zones, while the Building Products & Furnishings industry does not have a similar flood zone reporting requirement. This reflects the different nature of climate change risks faced by these industries.
references: IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Building Products & Furnishings
IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Real Estate

question: What is a key difference in sustainability reporting focus between the Building Products & Furnishings industry and the Real Estate industry according to IFRS standards?
optionA: Building Products & Furnishings focuses on product lifecycle, while Real Estate focuses on operational efficiency
optionB: Real Estate reports on tenant sustainability, while Building Products & Furnishings does not have a similar focus
optionC: Building Products & Furnishings emphasizes material sourcing, while Real Estate emphasizes location-based risks
optionD: Real Estate focuses on energy ratings, while Building Products & Furnishings focuses on product energy efficiency
optionE: There is no significant difference in sustainability reporting focus
answer: B: Real Estate reports on tenant sustainability, while Building Products & Furnishings does not have a similar focus
explanation: The Real Estate industry has specific requirements to report on tenant sustainability impacts (IF-RE-410a.1, IF-RE-410a.2, IF-RE-410a.3), including metrics related to tenant energy and water consumption and strategies for improving tenant sustainability. The Building Products & Furnishings industry does not have similar requirements focused on end-user or customer sustainability impacts.

IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Real Estate
